During peak harvest seasons, coffee pickers often work 10-12 hours a day, 6 to 7 days a week. This results in workweeks of 60-84 hours during these periods, well above the legal 48-hour limit. Assuming that during peak periods, coffee workers are working an average of 70 hours per week (vs. the legal limit of 48 hours), they are overworked by around 22 hours per week. During non-peak periods, work hours may be closer to the legal limit, though informal laborers may still experience some level of overwork, perhaps averaging 5-10 hours of excess work per week. Considering that peak harvest periods last for about 3 to 4 months annually, and accounting for non-peak periods, an average agricultural worker in coffee production could be overworked by 10-15 hours per week over the course of a year. Based on the assumption of 10-15 hours of overwork per week, coffee workers in Colombia may accumulate around 500-750 overworked hours per year.
